There are three types of balance: symmetrical, asymmetrical, and proportional. In a symmetrical balance, the visual weight is evenly distributed on both sides of a central point. This can be seen in the image on the left, which features two identical pictures that are mirror images of each other. In an asymmetrical balance, one side of the composition has more visual weight than the other. As shown in the picture on the right, one picture is larger and more prominent than the smaller one on the opposite side. Proportional balance refers to the distribution of size and shape within an image. For example, objects in a picture may be proportionally similar in size or shape, creating a sense of harmony and balance within the composition. In the image below, the two pictures on either side have different shapes and sizes, but the overall balance is maintained through the use of similar shapes and relative sizes. An important aspect of graphic design is the ability to create visual interest and draw the viewer's attention to specific areas or elements within a picture. This technique is called focalization, and it can be achieved by using contrast, color, shape, or texture to create a focal point or focal area within a design. In this image, the focal area is created by using a contrasting color and a unique shape to draw attention to the yellow circle in the middle of the picture. In summary, graphic design involves the creation of visually appealing images that effectively communicate a message or convey an idea. The principles of balance, symmetry, proportionality, and focalization are essential elements of successful graphic design.
